title: 114_s2949
content: The Act may be cited as the "Great Lakes Fish and Wildlife Restoration Act of 2016" and references amendments to the Great Lakes Fish and Wildlife Restoration Act of 1990. The Act is amended by striking section 1002 and inserting new findings. The Great Lakes Fish and Wildlife Restoration Act of 2016 acknowledges the changing ecosystems in the Great Lakes and emphasizes the need for coordinated efforts to manage fish and wildlife resources effectively. It supports activities in the Great Lakes Basin to protect these resources based on the recommendations of the Great Lakes Regional Collaboration. Additional actions and better coordination are deemed necessary for the protection and management of fish and wildlife in the region. The Great Lakes Fish and Wildlife Restoration Act of 2016 aims to protect and manage fish and wildlife resources in the Great Lakes Basin. It allows for federal agencies, states, and Indian tribes to collaborate effectively in funding restoration work. Amendments are made to identify, review, and implement proposals and regional projects for the conservation of these resources. The Great Lakes Fish and Wildlife Restoration Act of 2016 is amended to include the strategic action plan of the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative and State wildlife action plans. Amendments also remove references to the Great Lakes Coordinator and adjust cost-sharing requirements. The Great Lakes Fish and Wildlife Restoration Act of 2016 is amended to include the strategic action plan of the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative and State wildlife action plans. Amendments also adjust cost-sharing requirements, requiring a non-federal share of at least 25% of the cost of implementing a proposal or regional project, with the option to provide the match within a 2-year period preceding the application submission. The Great Lakes Fish and Wildlife Restoration Act of 2016 is amended to include the strategic action plan of the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative and State wildlife action plans. Amendments adjust cost-sharing requirements, with the Director authorized to determine the non-Federal share by considering the appraised value of land or conservation easements, or the costs associated with land acquisition or securing a conservation easement. The Director may use the appraised value of land or a conservation easement to fulfill the non-Federal share of implementing a proposal or regional project under the Great Lakes Fish and Wildlife Restoration Act of 2016. The land or conservation easement must meet specific requirements and be acquired before the end of the grant period. The land or conservation easement must be held in perpetuity for conservation purposes related to the Great Lakes Basin, connected to the proposal or regional project, and appraised accordingly. The appraisal of land or a conservation easement for conservation purposes related to the Great Lakes Basin must be done within 1 year of setting the price under a contract, following the Uniform Standards of Professional Appraisal Practice (USPAP). The costs of land acquisition or securing a conservation easement can be used to fulfill the non-Federal share of implementing a proposal or regional project, as long as the activities and expenses are related to the land acquisition or easement. The text discusses the costs related to securing a conservation easement and land restoration, including allowable costs such as cash, in-kind contributions, and indirect costs. It also specifies that costs associated with mitigation or litigation, except for those related to the Natural Resource Damage Assessment program, are not included. In subsection (b), the heading is changed from "Fishery Resources" to "Fish and Wildlife Conservation" and all instances of "Fishery Resources" are replaced with "Fish and Wildlife Conservation". Subsection (a) is removed and subsections (b) and (c) are redesignated as subsections (a) and (b) respectively. Section 1008 (16 U.S.C. 941f) is amended regarding reports. Section 1008 (16 U.S.C. 941f) is amended to update the timeline and actions related to the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative. The Director is required to continue monitoring the status and needs of fish and wildlife resources in the Great Lakes Basin. The amendment updates the timeline and actions for the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative, focusing on monitoring fish and wildlife resources in the Great Lakes Basin. Authorization of appropriations is adjusted for the period 2016 through 2021, with revised funding amounts for various activities. The amendment updates the activities of the Upper Great Lakes Fish and Wildlife Conservation Offices and the Lower Great Lakes Fish and Wildlife Conservation Office under section 1007. Section 8 of the Great Lakes Fish and Wildlife Restoration Act of 2006 is repealed.
